trial_identification.studytitle: Can robots improve quality of life in residents and staff in a residential care facility?
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Can robots improve quality of life in residents aged over 65 years and staff in a residential care facility?

conditions.healthcondition: Quality of life in residents of a residential care facility
Quality of life in staff at a residential care facility

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions: 3 robots will be placed in each of two buildings at the residential care facility. THe robots can measure vital signs (blood pressure, pulse oximetry, blood glucose), telecommunication (with family, friends, staff), brain fitness software and entertainment (show videos, photos), lifetime health diary (shows health records), and access to web based content (such as whats on at the retirement village that day). Staff and residents are free to use the robots at thier discretion. THe robots will be there for 4 months. This will be in addition to the standard care that is normally provided to the individuals at the residential care faciliity.
interventions.comparator: no robot - standard care, that is care normally provided to the individual at the residential care facility.

primaryOutcome.outcome: quality of life (measure with SF12 (staff) or QOL-AD (residents)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: depression - geriatric depression scale in residents only
job satisfaction and job morale for staff only thorugh self report qquestionnaires: Job Satisfaction Scale and Job Morale Scale

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: living or working in residential care (hospitals or rest homes) at Selwyn Village retirement centre (not independent apartments or villas) residents must be over 65 years Staff must be over 16 years
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Don't understand English Too unwell to participate

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This project aims to investigate whether robots can improve quality of life for residents and staff in residential care in a retirement village. This is a non-randomised between groups trial of 64 staff and 64 residents. There will be 3 robots in each of two buildings. The robots can take vital signs, provide entertainment and brain fitness games, have telecommunication, and provide information about activities at the village. The main outcome measures are resident quality of life, depression, and perceptions of the robots. For staff we are also measuring job satisfaction and morale.
